info.game_comments: Clip from this game was shown in the 1992 film Breaking the Rules

(1, 1).clue: This man's son, who helped his dad with the famous "kite experiment", sided with the Tories

(2, 1).clue: The Miss America Pageant stopped giving this award for friendliness in 1974

(3, 1).clue: A screwdriver is vodka & orange juice while a bloody Mary is vodka & this juice

(4, 1).clue: The title of Leo Sayer's 1st no. 1 hit proclaimed "You Make Me Feel Like" doing this

(5, 1).clue: In 1980 Jane Seymour played Mozart's wife on Broadway in this play

(6, 1).clue: Zeus originated as an Indo-European god of this, which gives him something in common with Willard Scott

(1, 2).clue: The British passed the Intolerable Acts to punish Massachusetts for this event

(2, 2).clue: She was Miss Mississippi & Miss America, & now she's Mrs. Gary Collins

(3, 2).clue: Under British law, Scotch whisky must be made with water from this region of Scotland

(4, 2).clue: In Ricky Nelson's "Garden Party" he stepped out of the closet "playing guitar like ringin' a bell"

(5, 2).clue: In 1977 Anne Bancroft returned to Broadway to play this Mideast leader

(6, 2).clue: Starting in 776 B.C., these were held quadrennially in honor of Zeus

(1, 3).clue: A S.C. merchant was captured at sea & charged room & board while imprisoned at this London landmark

(2, 3).clue: She was 1st runner-up in the 1940 Miss Venice Beach Contest -- she didn't look like Lily Munster yet

(3, 3).clue: Named for an island in the Netherlands Antilles, it's a liqueur flavored with orange peel

(4, 3).clue: Marie Osmond had real success with this 1973 song about artificial flowers

(5, 3).clue: Raquel Welch made her Broadway debut in this musical, replacing Lauren Bacall

(6, 3).clue: Though Zeus had over 100 mistresses, he chose her, his sister, to be his wife

(1, 4).clue: Though a symbol of the war, this organization of citizen-soldiers existed only for about 6 months

(2, 4).clue: This beauty contest title was taken away from Zsa Zsa Gabor because she was underage

(3, 4).clue: This tall rum drink shares its name with the stick you might use to stir it

(4, 4).clue: With 2 previous big hits, Gordon Lightfoot was cruising down a Carefree 1 of these in '74

(5, 4).clue: Jack Klugman sang with Ethel Merman in this musical, but he kept his clothes on

(6, 4).clue: Zeus led a revolt against this group & dethroned his father, Cronus

(1, 5).clue: This 2nd cousin of our 2nd president helped found the Sons of Liberty

(2, 5).clue: Formerly Miss South Dakota, she now co-hosts "Entertainment Tonight"

(3, 5).clue: A Scarlett O'Hara mixes cranberry juice, lime juice & this liquor

(4, 5).clue: In the '70s Elvis had only 2 top 10 hits, "The Wonder of You" & this hot number of 1972

(5, 5).clue: Before "Roots" LeVar Burton's only sizable role was as Ali Hakim in this musical at USC

(6, 5).clue: Zeus' 2 most important symbols were the eagle & this, hurled as a weapon

(1, 1).clue: It has more people than all the other South American nations combined

(3, 1).clue: 1st held in 1876, the Bayreuth Festival was planned by this German opera composer to play his own works

(4, 1).clue: "Canine" phrase used to describe rock collecting enthusiasts

(5, 1).clue: From Latin to "lie down on", the device in which premature babies lie down

(6, 1).clue: He warned his followers he could die in March 1987 if they didn't help him raise $8 million

(1, 2).clue: This North American mountain range is named for the waterfalls of the Columbia River

(3, 2).clue: Desiring a teacher, Gershwin sought out this composer of "Bolero", who told him he didn't need one

(4, 2).clue: This mineral is crushed, powdered & glued onto paper to make disposable nail boards

(5, 2).clue: From Latin for "an image", one of a hated person might be burned

(6, 2).clue: Sec'y of Defense thru much of the '60s, the Vietnam War was sometimes called his war

(1, 3).clue: It's the northernmost country that's a member of the Organization of American States

(3, 3).clue: Written in 1723, this German's "Magnificat in D Major" is magnificent

(4, 3).clue: This landmark at the mouth of the Mediterranean is a large block of limestone

(5, 3).clue: One dying for his faith, like a Christian thrown to lions, is called this from the Greek for "witness"

(6, 3).clue: Die-hard basketball fans remember him as "The Big O"

(1, 4).clue: Yellowknife, Canada's smallest capital, is capital of this territory

(4, 4).clue: In "America the Beautiful", type of white gypsum used to describe the gleam of the cities

(5, 4).clue: From the Greek for "a race track", Circus Maximus in Rome was an example of this type of equestrian arena

(6, 4).clue: Though he directed the team that made the 1st atomic bomb, he opposed making the hydrogen bomb

(1, 5).clue: Though this British colony has only 19,000 people, as of 1982 it had over 400 licenses banks

(3, 5).clue: He composed "Faust" &, in 1869, the Vatican National Anthem

(4, 5).clue: Kimberlite, a mineral in which diamonds are found, was named for a city in this country

(5, 5).clue: This fancy word for an indoor swimming pool is Latin for "a place for swimming"

(6, 5).clue: This humorist wrote short pieces for The New Yorker & made short subjects for M-G-M

(0, 0).clue: In 1542 this island group was named for the future King of Spain
